Award.AwardTitle: Scientific Inquiry and Process: A Design for the Times

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: In this project, a team at the University of La Verne is adapting its successful strategy for teaching junior-level cell biology laboratory, called Design Your Own Experiment (DYOE). It is now being combined with activities promoting scientific literacy and the course targeted to the sophomore-level. In response to increased enrollment, the class size has increased so that laboratory equipment must be shared. When not actively working with the equipment, students develop their skills in reading, writing, and speaking about topics in cell biology through journal club, critiquing and writing about the scientific literature and the students' own written scientific work, and preparing data for presentation. The approach is also being tested in a second course, Developmental Biology. The team is developing assessment instruments to evaluate the success of the combination of DYOE and literacy work in improving overall student learning. The model is likely to be attractive to many schools experiencing enrollment increases without a corresponding increase in resources. A tangible product of the project is a laboratory manual, customizable by the adopter, in both student and instructor editions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of STEM education has moved beyond merely identifying and developing innovative, effective science pedagogies and into adopting and adapting effective approaches. However, major barriers to widespread adoption of effective pedagogies remain, such as having cost-effective approaches, strategies for implementation on a broader scale, and tools for assessment of implementation. The NSF TUES project at the University of La Verne (ULV) developed an approach to implementation that was low-cost, easily adapted, and assessable, and that was shown to be effective. Quantitative and qualitative measures were used to assess student learning gains in critical thinking (Critical Thinking Assessment Test, CAT) and mastery of a variety of science practice outcomes (Classroom Undergraduate Research Experience, CURE survey), as a result of the intervention. CAT pre- to post-course data analysis showed that students improved critical thinking skills. For the three-year period from 2012-2015 the average gain was 0.94, 2.11, and 3.12, respectively, with gains in years two and three being statistically significant (p < 0.05). CAT national user norms predicted that students with incoming SAT scores of 1030 (verbal & quantitative), such as ULV students, would earn 18.58 points (out of a possible 38 points) when assessed as upper division students (juniors or seniors). Even with the error associated with institutional scoring, ULV students performed better than the predicted norms. Seniors scored 21.41 points on average (p <0.001).

 From the CURE survey, perceived learning gains of ULV students matched or exceeded gains reported by students from other institutions engaged in classroom or summer research experiences. Differences in gains in categories such as ‘becoming part of a learning community’, ‘understanding how scientists think’, ‘ability to read and understand primary literature’, ‘learning laboratory techniques’, ‘learning ethical conduct’, ‘understanding science’, ‘ability to analyze data and other information’, understanding scientific assertions require supporting evidence’, ‘understanding how scientists work on real problems’, ‘ability to integrate theory and practice’, ‘understanding the research process’, ‘understanding how knowledge is constructed’, and ‘skill in interpretation of results’ were statistically significant (p <0.05).

ULV is a Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI) serving a majority of students of color, women, and receiving financial aid, approximately 40% first generation college attendees. These results suggest that these underserved groups may derive significant benefit from the DYOE/CURE approach.

There are three areas in which this project has impacted society beyond the science and technology fields. They are teacher training, workforce development, and cross-disciplinary collaborations. Development of the DYOE/CURE pedagogy has improved STEM education and educator development at the undergraduate training level. Teaching-track students are required to take at least one DYOE/CURE course at ULV. These students are encouraged to “peek behind the curtain” by discussing the pedagogy with the faculty who teach the DYOE/CURE courses. In that way, teaching-track students are exposed to and participate in engaged pedagogies that have been shown to be effective in promoting student success. Having an opportunity to engage in the pedagogy encourages the teaching-track students to use the pedagogy when they have their own classroom, adding a highly effective, proven teaching tool to their teaching toolbox.

The observed improvements in critical thinking (CAT) and self-reported learning gains such as ‘understanding how scientists think’, ‘ability to read and understand primary literature’, ‘learning laboratory techniques’, ‘learning ethical conduct’, ‘understanding science’, ‘ability to analyze data and other information’, understanding scientific assertions require supporting evidence’, ‘understanding how scientists work on real problems’, ‘becoming part of a learning community’, ‘ability to integrate theory and practice’, ‘understanding the research process’, ‘understanding how knowledge is constructed’, and ‘skill in interpretation of results’ suggest that students trained through DYOE/CURE courses will be better prepared for the challenges of STEM and other careers. It also implies that this approach can be used for development of a diverse and competitive STEM workforce, as the population of students served at the University of La Verne is majority students of color, female, and receiving federal financial aid (low SES).

The third impact beyond science and technology is cross-disciplinary collaborations. The success enjoyed by the Biology department in running DYOE/CURE courses has led to interest and opportunities for collaborations with other departments. Particularly the behavioral sciences (anthropology and sociology) and non-traditional STEM fields like kinesiology at the University of La Verne have sought out collaborations in order to adopt the DYOE/CURE model. Adoption of the DYOE/CURE model through cross-disciplinary collaborations paves the way for more widespread success for underserved students, as high impact practices like undergraduate research opportunities have been shown to disproportionately, positively impact these students.
